results.title: Radioactive boars and anime

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description: A Twitter response to a news article about the infestation of aggressive, radioactive boars in the radioactive area around Fukushima, Japan.
description_for_label: A Twitter response to a news article about the infestation of aggressive, radioactive boars in the radioactive area around Fukushima, Japan.

constellations_other.name: If at first you don't succeed
constellations_other.description: Though originally intended as a laugh, Celeste Baber’s social media posts have become examples of body positivity to her eight million followers and challenge the absurd expectations put on women in society.

results.title: The Promise
results.brief_description: Julie Gough’s The Promise (2011) uses light and shadow to illuminate the mistreatment of First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
The Promise 2011

found chair, shadow casting LED light, kangaroo skin

Private collection

Exhibited in: THE MISSING, Bett Gallery, Hobart, June – July 2011 (solo exhibition)
description_for_label:

results.title: Data Tapestry
results.brief_description: Data Tapestry is a commissioned data-art work for the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV) Melbourne Now exhibition. The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.description:
Data Tapestry is a commissioned data-art work for the National Gallery of Victoria (NGV) Melbourne Now exhibition. The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.

Working with a curatorial team, data researchers, and collaborating city organisations, we sourced a range of open datasets, and less accessible data, to present different themes of the city: for example 5 years of Melbourne traffic accidents, city trees, waterways, buildings etc. These were presented through a 4 HD projections and 4 channels of audio.

Artist statement about data visualisation

As an artform data visualisation enables patterns to emerge from vast amounts of data. This data echoes the physical world we live in and rendered through a combination of design, programming & digital technology, data visualisation allows us to experience our world in new ways. As a designer data visualisation is not confined to the statistical or the analytical, but is an opportunity to explore the poetics inherent in data – a form of data aesthetics. Similar to words in language, or notes in music, visual & sonic encoding gives shape to data, it poises questions, and expands knowledge, and lets us sense - and in turn make sense - of our physical and informational environments.

Information via http://www.oomcreative.com/project/oom-ngv-data-tapestry.html
description_for_label:

results.title: Mickey Mouse Model Sheet
results.credit_line:
Disney Studio Artist

Clean-up model sheet

Photostat on paper
results.description:
Mickey Mouse was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks, one of the leading animators of the time. Mickey Mouse first appeared to the public in Steamboat Willie, which was released in 1928. In an era when movies were moving from silent movies to “talkies”, which had synchronised sound, this film was the world’s first-ever “talkie” animation. The first films produced featuring Mickey Mouse were silent movies, including Plane Crazy (1928) and The Gallopin’ Gaucho (1928), which were completed prior to Steamboat Willie, but were released afterwards, when sound was finally added to them. Walt Disney supplied the voice of Mickey Mouse himself and would go on to voice Mickey for another 20 years.

This model sheet of Mickey Mouse represents the way that early animators had to learn how to make drawings move when they were animated. While this one only shows Mickey Mouse, they are created for all characters so that artists can convey all the principles of movement, including the effects of weight and heaviness, as well as what they’ll look like stretching or bouncing. It’s the art behind the animation and required studying physics and anatomy to create realistic, though fantastical, characters.
description_for_label:
Mickey Mouse was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks, one of the leading animators of the time. Mickey Mouse first appeared to the public in Steamboat Willie, which was released in 1928. In an era when movies were moving from silent movies to “talkies”, which had synchronised sound, this film was the world’s first-ever “talkie” animation. The first films produced featuring Mickey Mouse were silent movies, including Plane Crazy (1928) and The Gallopin’ Gaucho (1928), which were completed prior to Steamboat Willie, but were released afterwards, when sound was finally added to them. Walt Disney supplied the voice of Mickey Mouse himself and would go on to voice Mickey for another 20 years.

This model sheet of Mickey Mouse represents the way that early animators had to learn how to make drawings move when they were animated. While this one only shows Mickey Mouse, they are created for all characters so that artists can convey all the principles of movement, including the effects of weight and heaviness, as well as what they’ll look like stretching or bouncing. It’s the art behind the animation and required studying physics and anatomy to create realistic, though fantastical, characters.

results.title: MPL TESt
results.description: Around 2015, Emmy Award-winning filmmaker Jody Eldred tested a pre-production model of the BlackMagic URSA Mini 4.6K in the Las Vegas desert. Aside from his 40-year career in film and TV, Eldred had spent 15 years testing cameras. “Wow,” was his response to the camera’s quality, but he had a few suggestions for on how to improve it. Less than a year later the URSA Mini Pro 4.6k was released with those changes implemented. “I was stunned,” Eldred has said of a camera company who listened to its users.

constellations_other.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_other.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million YouTube views. It's tongue-in-cheek approach to reflects a unique way of advertising that cuts through and make an impact, like the other ads featured in this Constellation.

results.title: I Touch Myself

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

results.description: The Divnyls’ hit single ‘I Touch Myself’ launched the band’s popularity into the stratosphere, with the single reaching #4 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number one in Australia. The music video was directed by blockbuster and explosions aficionado Michael Bay and was nominated for three MTV Video Music Awards, including Video of the Year.

results.title: Looky Looky Here Comes Cooky

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description: A songline for 21st century Australia – a fresh look at the Cook legend from a First Nations’ perspective – the songline tells of connection to country, resistance and survival and features the cheeky, acerbic and heartfelt showman – Steven Oliver and a host of outstanding Indigenous singer/songwriters.
